'term Launches stetaoned on Joact bo- t eon Tibbs end Lboi Irlbf could, I should think, effectively prevent gun running dhor/s from proceeding up the ,‘orst and compel them to make a longer run across to oiabaruor the Tokran does it this view is coxiOct, r decision that whe six ip of erst mentioned above is not in the iuxisdict-on of the Sultan should be of resistance to :!is ajosty ? s Ships in suppressing the arms traffic* On the oth'r hand perhaps it iray be considoxod that to take up the question strongly would only exrepoit tc r nrlJ^rts His - r^hness t:.c ::ultan, and that consequently it would be bettox to take no action in regard to it, unless we a^e forced to do so* i have therefore deemed it advisable to lay the case befoxe you and obtain instxuctions bcfo.o taking any action in the matter. I have the honour to be. Lir, loux meet obedient servant* i • X M 0 S C iiNo. /0 6~^ of 1910 © British Residency and Consulate-General To The Political Agent MUSCAT. Sir I have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 5S7 dated ‘13rd April 1910 reporting overtures on the part of Jowasim representatives of Khor Fakan and the Jasmi Dibba to His Highness the Sultan. °• There has been no change of the attitude of Government towards the question ot the Jasmi enclave on the Oman Coast> and it will oe advisable that you make the visits of Abdullah bin Simui and Saeed bin Hamud an occasion for reiterating the warning which has been periodically administered to His Highness, against encouraging the disloyal intrigues of these dependents of the Sheikk. of Shargah or interfering in their affairs. o. As regards the Sheikh of Kumzar, the information given you by khan Saheb Mohamed bin Saeed probably arises from some misconcep tion on his part. As you suggest in paragraph 4 of your letter we specifically stated in the counterdraft presented to the Hague Tribunal in French Flag Arbitration that the Sultan of Muscat claimed jurisdiction over kd® tract between Dibba and Tibba, and in the course of subsequent correspondence in connection with the ran oval of the flagstaff on Telegraph Island in the Elphinstone' the secretary of State p or India, on the ground that we had admit ted these claims, expressed the opinion that the flagstaff should not be maintained, though it need not be removed, as to do so might attract unnecessary attention. His Majesty’s Foreign Office then in their despatch No. 36810/07 dated 9th-May 1908 to the India(5) India Office accepted the view that the flagstaff should not bo maintained. There the matter rests as far as my record is concerned and n ■■ as I think Kumzar. treated as under iihasab where the oultan keeps a A Wali, there can be no uncertainty for present purposes as to the status of the Kumzar Sheikh or the Dibba - Tibba Coast line. 4. I agree that it would be more convenient from the Blockade point of view if the Musandum promontory were not under Muscat, but the operations of His Majesty's dhipa are not seriously hamp ered in practice by niceties of jurisdiction, and the record does not leave the question sufficiently in doubt for me to reopen it with uovernment at the present juncture. I have the honour to be Sir Your most obedient servant Lt.Colonel Political Resident in the Persian Gulf

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: 'File 8/39 MUSCAT STATE AFFAIRS: CLAIM OF INDEPENDENCE BY KHOR FAKHAN AND DHIBBA SHAIKHS'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 8, these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. A previous foliation sequence, which is also circled, has been superseded and therefore crossed out.

mods.abstract: This file consists of two letters exchanged between the Political Agent and Consul, Muscat, and the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. It concerns the British response to news that the Shaikhs of Dibba and Khor Fakan [Khawr Fakkān] have recently declared themselves to be no longer subordinate to the Shaikh of Shargah [Sharjah] but instead under the jurisdiction of the Sultan of Muscat and Oman.
